scenarios.situation: You're approaching a busy roundabout. Traffic is flowing steadily from the right. A cyclist is ahead of you.

choices.text: Slow to 20km/h, check right mirror, shoulder check, yield to traffic, then enter when clear
choices.feedback: Perfect! Excellent observation and positioning. The shoulder check for the cyclist was crucial.

choices.text: Maintain 40km/h and enter quickly to avoid holding up traffic behind
choices.feedback: Dangerous! You must yield to traffic from the right. Speed and impatience cause fails. This would be marked as a Grade 3 fault.

choices.text: Stop completely at the yield line and wait 5 seconds before proceeding
choices.feedback: Over-cautious. You should yield but not stop unnecessarily when it's clear. This causes traffic disruption.

scenarios.situation: You're merging onto the N81. Speed limit is 80km/h. Traffic in the left lane is moving at 75km/h.

choices.text: Accelerate smoothly to 75km/h, check mirrors, signal, and merge when safe gap appears
choices.feedback: Excellent! You matched traffic speed and merged safely. Good use of mirrors and signals.

choices.text: Merge at 50km/h - better to be safe than sorry
choices.feedback: Too slow! Merging well below traffic speed creates a hazard. You need to match the flow of traffic.

choices.text: Accelerate to 85km/h to get ahead of traffic before merging
choices.feedback: Speeding! Never exceed the limit, even when merging. Match traffic speed within the legal limit.

scenarios.situation: You're on a narrow street with cars parked on both sides. A child's ball rolls into the road 30m ahead.

choices.text: Immediately slow down, cover the brake, scan for the child, and be prepared to stop completely
choices.feedback: Perfect hazard perception! You anticipated that a child might follow the ball. This is exactly what examiners look for.

choices.text: Maintain speed but sound horn to warn any children
choices.feedback: Wrong! Sounding the horn doesn't remove the danger. You must slow down. This shows poor hazard awareness.

choices.text: Swerve around the ball to maintain progress
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Never swerve suddenly - you could hit an oncoming car or lose control. Always slow down first.

scenarios.situation: The examiner asks you to reverse around the corner on your left. There's a lamppost on the corner.

choices.text: Check all mirrors, signal left, stop parallel to kerb, then reverse slowly with constant observation all around, keeping within 30cm of kerb
choices.feedback: Textbook reversing! Constant observation and good positioning. You stayed close to the kerb without mounting it.

choices.text: Reverse quickly to show confidence, steering sharply to get around fast
choices.feedback: Too fast! Manoeuvres should be slow and controlled. You risk hitting the kerb or the lamppost. This would fail you.

choices.text: Position 50cm from kerb and reverse, focusing mainly on the rear window
choices.feedback: Poor positioning - you're too far from the kerb. You must also check all around, not just the rear.

scenarios.situation: You need to turn right at a T-junction onto a busy main road. Visibility is limited due to a hedge.

choices.text: Approach slowly, stop at the line, creep forward for better view, check both ways multiple times, wait for a safe gap
choices.feedback: Excellent! You compensated for poor visibility by creeping forward. Patient waiting for a proper gap shows good judgement.

choices.text: Edge out quickly to get a view, then commit to the turn if there's any gap
choices.feedback: Dangerous! Edging out quickly with limited visibility could cause a collision. Always creep forward slowly.

choices.text: Wait at the line for 30 seconds to be sure it's safe
choices.feedback: Over-cautious. You must creep forward to improve visibility - you can't see properly from the line due to the hedge.
